originalQuestion.question: When did President Biden sign the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act into law?
originalQuestion.hint: Signed two days before the actual holiday.
originalQuestion.explanation: Biden signed the law on June 17, 2021, making it the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King Jr. Day in 1983—a 38-year gap that shows how reluctant America is to recognize Black freedom. The timing meant 2.1 million federal workers got the day off just two days later, proving that when political will exists, change can happen immediately.

sources.name: Biden signs bill making Juneteenth a federal holiday
Biden Signs Juneteenth Holiday Into Law

The timing meant 2.1 million federal workers got the day off just two days later, proving that when political will exists, change can happen immediately.

originalQuestion.question: Which Texas Congresswoman led the decades-long fight to make Juneteenth a federal holiday?
originalQuestion.hint: Houston representative who never gave up.
originalQuestion.explanation: Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee introduced Juneteenth holiday legislation for over 20 years, calling it "the true independence day for African Americans." She first introduced legislation in 1997 and faced years of parliamentary roadblocks and Republican opposition. Her persistence finally paid off when George Floyd's murder created political momentum that polite requests never could.

originalQuestion.question: How did Congress vote on making Juneteenth a federal holiday?
originalQuestion.hint: Senate was unanimous, but some House Republicans opposed.
originalQuestion.explanation: The Senate passed it unanimously, but 14 House Republicans voted against recognizing the end of slavery as a federal holiday. These Republicans argued it was too expensive or created "confusion" with July 4th—revealing how some politicians still resist acknowledging Black liberation as worthy of national celebration.

originalQuestion.question: What is the name of the 98-year-old activist Biden called the "grandmother of Juneteenth"?
originalQuestion.hint: Texas activist who walked from Fort Worth to Washington.
originalQuestion.explanation: Opal Lee walked from Fort Worth to Washington D.C. at age 89 to advocate for federal recognition, earning her the title "grandmother of Juneteenth." Biden honored her at the White House signing ceremony, noting that a white mob torched her family home when she was 12 on June 19, 1939, but "such hate never stopped her" from fighting for recognition of Black freedom.

originalQuestion.question: The push for federal Juneteenth recognition gained momentum after George Floyd's murder and nationwide protests.
originalQuestion.hint: Racial justice movement created political pressure.
originalQuestion.explanation: The 2020 racial justice protests following George Floyd's murder created political momentum that decades of polite advocacy couldn't achieve. Nine states designated Juneteenth a paid holiday in the year following Floyd's death, and federal recognition followed. This shows how crisis and mass action can force recognition that incremental advocacy cannot secure.
